admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Rehabilitation Loan
            Project for Estonia were as follows: Bank performance was
            satisfactory; and Borrower performance was highly
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: the built-in
            flexibility and indicative policy targets included in the
            memorandum of economic reform policies (MERP), coupled with
            strong technical support for both the import and policy
            components, have contributed to the successful
            implementation of the loan with the prerequisite of a strong
            and sustained government commitment to a well-defined reform
            agenda. The appointment of procurement advisors who provided
            overall project management support was very important for
            the success of an operation in a new borrowing country; the
            role of advisors should also stress responsibility for
            training local counterparts. Higher than average resources
            are needed when working with new borrowers and in loans that
            include policy components; the flexible design and the list
            of agreed imports increased supervision costs; however, the
            benefits reaped in terms of imports acceptable to the
            government, and building sectoral dialogue were substantial.
